executive_summary: Rising utility costs have put considerable pressure on the laundromat industry. However, following the Federal Reserve's decision to aggressively raise interest rates multiple times in 2022-2023, a tighter policy has affected budgets and decreased disposable income, favoring the industry. So, industry-wide revenue has increased at a CAGR of 0.5% over the past five years, including an estimated 1.5% decrease in 2023 and is expected to total $6.6 billion. In the same year, profit is projected to increase to 22.2%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising laundromat demand linked to economic challenges, housing volatility and seasonal factors
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During recessionary periods and housing market volatility, laundromat usage typically increases as more people cannot afford to purchase or repair laundry machines and opt for rental housing. Seasonality also plays a role in laundromat demand, with a significant share of revenue generated from college students during the year's first, second and fourth quarters. As rental vacancy rates drop, more renters occupy properties. Many rental properties lack personal laundry appliances, leading to increased need for laundromat services among these renters.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Laundromats can take advantage of their location
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The success of laundromats largely hinges on location because services and prices often fail to significantly differentiate one from another. Hence, proximity to consumers becomes critical. Laundromats can reduce competition by taking advantage of high consumer volume in urban areas like New York City, Washington, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Several Laundromat Service Companies Have Recognized the Benefits of Developing Apps for Their Business
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Apps enable users to install and use a laundry service application effortlessly, facilitating the organization of orders or the request for collection and delivery of their laundry. For instance, HamperApp is a real-time laundry service application that links busy individuals with nearby laundry professionals who can cater to their laundry needs. Utilizing this application in the industry enhances the existing digital presence and precisely targets potential customers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Increase in Utility Costs Has Caused Companies to Exit the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry faces difficulties due to fierce competition, escalating utility costs and shifting consumer behaviors towards home washer and dryer laundry appliances. Companies cannot pass on increases in utility costs to customers at higher prices because of the risk of losing existing clients in a competitive industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Economic Contraction Will Lead to a Boosted Demand for Laundromat Services
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The rising interest rates in 2022-2023 by the Federal Reserve will dampen demand for housing, increasing the need for rental properties, which are the industry's largest target market. Interest rate hikes make products like washing and dryer machines more expensive; this impacts consumers, prompting them to seek alternative, cost-effective ways to wash their clothes, like laundromat services.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue Will Continue To Suffer As Competition Increases
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competition from substitute products and services like dry cleaners and laundromats that offer pickup and drop-off laundry will increase, resulting in a drop in overall sales. As per capita disposable income rises, more Americans can afford drop-off and pick-up laundry and dry-cleaning services, undermining industry revenue. However, these services are more expensive than those in this industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Laundromats Will Embrace Energy Efficiency And Smart Technology
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Laundromats will keep adopting innovative washers and dryers that use significantly less energy and water for a more eco-friendly operation to reduce utility costs and boost profit. Card-operated machines and loyalty card systems will enhance user experiences and streamline pricing strategies. Their persistence ensures customer convenience while enabling businesses to adjust prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Utilities Costs Will Continue To Exert Pressure On The Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Laundromats will continue to operate their washers and dryers using electricity; hence, any hike in utility costs could negatively impact the business. Innovations may reduce, but not eliminate, this considerable cost. A minor drop in the price of electric power will hike average profit, providing a glimmer of hope for laundromats in the competitive industry.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry primarily manage facilities with coin-operated or similar laundry and dry-cleaning equipment for customer use on the premises. Laundromats also supply and service coin-operated, smart card or other similar laundry machines.
key_trends: The drop in home ownership in 2022-2023, because of recessionary pressures, has led to an expansion of laundromat services. More people cannot afford the repair, replacement, or purchase of new washers and dryers, so they are compelled to seek alternatives.
Laundromats can take advantage of their location. Since most laundromats are nondifferentiable concerning service or price, laundromats' success is dependent on proximity to consumers.
Some regulations vary at the state and local levels. Laundromats must frequently contact local business administration offices to determine which licenses are required.

The Laundromats industry typically does not receive federal assistance through subsidies or otherwise. The key industry association is the Coin Laundry Association (CLA), which produces surveys with industry statistics, financial information and developing trends.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The segment includes renters using coin-operated machines provided by landlords or renters going to laundromats.

The segment includes hotels, motels, hostels and restaurants. Hotels, motels and other accommodation establishments will sometimes offer guests on-site coin-operated washers and dryers as an added service.

Many colleges and universities offer laundry facilities for their students, typically operated through a coin- or card-based system. These are managed by professional laundromat services, ensuring efficiency and convenience.
These segments include homeowners who either don't own their own washer and dryer or have laundry appliances but use laundromats to do larger loads of laundry.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment comprises establishments offering public access to laundry appliances like washing machines.
This segment comprises establishments offering public access to laundry appliances like drying machines.

tier_1_suppliers: Electrical Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Major Household Appliance Manufacturing in the US
Soap & Cleaning Compound Manufacturing in the US
Pump & Compressor Manufacturing in the US
Plumbing & Heating Supplies Wholesaling in the US
Drug, Cosmetic & Toiletry Wholesaling in the US
Electrical Equipment Wholesaling in the US
TV & Appliance Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Volatile economic conditions have led to an increase in profits. The actual economic downturn has triggered a decrease in consumer spending, prompting individuals to search for more cost-effective alternatives for doing laundry.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region exhibits fierce competition because of the high number of establishments. These businesses significantly outnumber the revenue they create, demonstrating intense rivalry for market share.
The Southeast is the most populous region in the United States. Establishments are less prominent in the region because a higher percentage of the population lives in suburban or rural areas.

Large urban areas like Los Angeles, San Francisco and Seattle in the West offer strategic locations for laundromats because of high population density and high rents limiting space for personal washing machines. The West hosts a significant percentage of the nation's colleges and universities, second only to other regions.

regulations_points.regulation_description: CFR is the codification of the general and permanent rules published in the Federal Register by the departments and agencies of the Federal Government. Most CFR-related laundromat regulations govern the handling, generation, storage and disposal of pollutants.
The EPCA establishes energy conservation standards for a variety of consumer products as well as certain commercial and industrial equipment, like commercial clothes washers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: SOME REGULATIONS VARY AT THE STATE AND LOCAL LEVELS
regulations_points.regulation_description: Laundromats must frequently contact local business administration offices to determine which licenses are required.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Laundromats possess a high level of capital intensity, primarily because of the acquisition of washing machines, dryers, coin changers and computers.

basis_points.basis_title: Laundromats compete mainly based on price, quality of service, location and extra services offered.
basis_points.basis_description: There is significant price-based competition in the industry.

basis_points.basis_title: External competition from home washers and dryers
basis_points.basis_description: The industry experiences external competition from sales of washers and dryers that are non-coin operated and purchased primarily for the home. The price of home washers and dryers has steadily decreased.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Laundromats industry continues to be highly fragmented, characterized by numerous small, privately owned businesses, often run by families, which prevent industry-wide standardization and dominance.
Laundromats predominantly operate without employees. Almost half of the companies in this industry function independently, without the need for a workforce, reflecting a self-service business model.
Laundromats located in areas with a high proportion of residents renting units and in densely populated areas with rising population levels will give the industry a competitive advantage.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Utility Prices are the Primary Concern Among Laundromats
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Electricity power is essential for operating laundry equipment like washers and dryers. Any hike in power costs creates havoc in laundromats, impacting their operational expenses.
Rising utility costs during the period have significantly impacted companies, forcing some to exit the industry or consolidate operations. These costs can't be transferred to customers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The cost of purchasing new machines can be quite high
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Laundromats are considering a switch to more energy-efficient washers to minimize long-term expenses. Larger companies can negotiate discounted equipment and cleaning supplies prices because of their stronger purchasing power.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Laundromats possess a high level of capital intensity
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Primarily because of the acquisition of washing machines, dryers, coin changers and computers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue is Adversely Affected by the Rise in Per Capita Disposable Income
volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility links closely to industry trends and economic conditions. Consumer willingness to purchase appliances like washers and dryers when disposable income rises.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Rising housing market instability leads to higher consumer preference for renting
volatility_points.volatility_description: This shift escalates demand for the Laundromats industry as more tenants require laundry facilities.

volatility_points.volatility_title: RISING UTILITY COSTS ARE THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF CONCERN FOR LAUNDROMAT OWNERS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Laundromat sales have struggled because of increasing utility costs and changed consumer habits. The increase in utility costs has caused companies to exit the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The industry demonstrates mild annual revenue shifts because of the continual need for cloth hygiene.
volatility_points.volatility_description: This perpetual necessity for clean clothes aids in steadying industry earnings.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: WASHER AND DRYER SERVICES COMPRISE THE LARGEST INDUSTRY SEGMENT
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment comprises establishments offering public access to laundry appliances like washing and drying machines. These facilities operate by coin, card or a store attendant's assistance.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: SELF-SERVICE DRY CLEANING DECLINES AS CASUAL CLOTHING BECOMES MORE POPULAR
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This segment includes self-service dry-cleaning services but excludes dry-cleaning services performed by attendants, like those provided by the Dry Cleaners industry (IBISWorld report 81232).

Commercial laundry services include the revenue generated from operating washers and dryers in motels, hospitals, clinics and other business institutions that already own their linen or uniforms and need laundry services.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Many Other Services Account for the Rest of the Industry
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The segment generates revenue by selling merchandise to customers and installing replacement parts for laundry machinery and equipment used primarily in commercial or service industry establishments.

FAQs.question: Are your sales reliant on the overall health of the US economy (i.e. consumer spending and per capita disposable income)? How has your business been impacted by the changes in consumer sentiment amid the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: The industry is inversely related to growth in the economy, typically increasing in times of lower disposable income and high unemployment levels and decreasing in times of economic prosperity and increased spending. As a result, changes in consumer spending patterns that have come since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic may benefit some industry players.

FAQs.question: How has your business been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic?
FAQs.answer: The vast majority of industry establishments were deemed essential during the nationwide stay-at-home in 2020 to slow the spread of COVID-19. Despite this, laundromats were still negatively impacted by consumers opting to spend more time at home than usual.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer a referral rewards program to attract new customers?
FAQs.answer: Laundromats have increasingly offered loyalty programs that give certain benefits, such as discounts and coupons, to returning customers.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in high-traffic areas to maximize visibility? Has the area your based in seen any significant changes in population density since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: A key success factor for laundromats is the ability to take advantage of location benefits. Since most laundromats do not differ drastically, success is dependent on proximity to consumers. There has been a spike in demand for residential housing in less densely populated areas since the pandemic began. This may have had a negative impact on some industry operators located in typically densely populated urban areas.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer ancillary services to diversify revenue streams?
FAQs.answer: Some laundromats offer dry-cleaning services and wash and fold. Additionally, most laundromats sell products needed for washing and drying, such as detergent and drying sheets.

FAQs.question: Is your company leveraging new technology, such as mobile phone applications, to streamline booking and communication with customers?
FAQs.answer: Laundromats are implementing internet applications that allow consumers to monitor the status of washers and dryers. Additionally, mobile applications such as FasCard, allow customers to check machine availability and manage their loyalty account.

FAQs.question: What new technologies have you employed in recent years?
FAQs.answer: New technology allows industry operators to link each washer and dryer to a centralized data bank. The system allows companies to track the number of coins taken in by each machine and provides information about usage and maintenance.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'? How has profitability been impacted by the ongoing coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Average profit margins decreased in 2020 due to intense internal competition and unfavorable operating conditions due to COVID-19. Profit is expected to remain lower even after the impacts of the pandemic have faded due to heavy competition.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company have to replace its equipment? How do you typically finance larger purchases?
FAQs.answer: The average lifespan of a washer is between 10 and 14 years and a dryer's average lifespan is between 10 and 13 years. Laundromats must ensure that their machines are working and efficient in order to retain customers, as well as attract new consumers.

FAQs.question: What measures do you have in place to reduce operational costs? Are you considering any new cost-saving measures? Has the pandemic led to any increased costs?
FAQs.answer: Effectively managing costs, including increasing utility prices, is important for success because profit margins tend to be low. The pandemic may have increased costs as some operators may be required to ensure their facilities are regularly disinfected.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? What are the associated costs? What new technologies have you employed in recent years?
FAQs.answer: To reduce costs, it is important to evaluate new energy- and water-saving washer and dryer equipment and the benefits of a card-based system.

FAQs.question: Are your facilities able to be adapted to comply with local social-distancing guidelines? Do guidelines prevent your business from operating at full capacity?
FAQs.answer: Many local governments have implemented new guidelines aimed at helping business operators continue operating in a safe fashion. These guidelines may include measures such as limiting the number of patrons allowed in a location at a given time, which could have an adverse effect on an operator's revenue.

FAQs.question: How is your business affected during periods of lower disposable income? How has your business been impacted amid lower consumer confidence caused by the economic impacts of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic?
FAQs.answer: As per capita disposable income increases, more-expensive laundry alternatives become available to consumers. With growing incomes, consumers can afford to purchase laundry machines and pay for drop-off laundry services, reducing demand for laundromats. Due to higher unemployment and lower consumer confidence, many consumers may opt to continue using industry services rather than purchase an in-home washer and dryer in the near future.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor the price of electric power? Do you offer energy-efficient products? How do you work to minimize utility costs for your business?
FAQs.answer: A considerable amount of energy is required for laundromat operations. Given the lack of viable substitutes among the industry's low-income consumers, industry operators can, in most cases, pass along a portion of the utility price increase, positively impacting revenue.

FAQs.question: How heavily do you rely on revenue from universities and colleges? How has your business been impacted since many universities have transitioned to remote learning amid the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Colleges and universities account for a prominent share of demand for industry services. This is because the industry provides colleges and universities with coin- or card-operated washers and dryers. Therefore, when enrollment increases, more students purchase laundry services. Since the initial outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic in early 2020, many universities have offered remote instruction, lowering the amount of students on and near campuses, posing a threat to operators that are dependent on college students.
